awd_titl_txt: NeTS: Small: Improving Web User Experience Using Eye Gaze
awd_abstract_narration:
Web page access is one of the most popular applications on the global Internet, and is a key element of the digital engine that drives the economy.   While the technologies that support Web applications are well-developed and ubiquitous, mechanisms for high quality user experience have not been built into their development. (As one example, almost every user has experienced delays in accessing content while ads download.)  Existing techniques for Web optimization focus on ensuring fast downloads, but research has shown that this has poor correlation with good user experience.  Further, download speeds are limited by network conditions; network congestion or low access network bandwidth can make them painfully slow. This project aims to address this problem by developing techniques for Web page optimization that significantly improve user experience by downloading the content of value to the user first.  

This project's primary goal is to ensure that objects on a Web page are loaded in the order in which the user consumes them, thus significantly improving user experience. The key idea is to use user's eye gaze as a signal for user's consumption of Web objects (or alternately the user interest). The project will develop novel techniques to use gaze signal to prioritize Web page loads, using commercial eye-tracking technology, and leveraging the researchers' experience in eye-tracking in other applications. The fundamental contributions of this project are to (1) Develop a utility-driven optimization framework to dynamically reprioritize Web page loads based on the user eye gaze, object sizes, and network conditions; (2) Remove the human-in-the-loop by building high-level saliency models of eye gaze based on the characteristics of the Web page. The gaze tracking will only be used infrequently, to seed and update the model.  (3) Design a large scale crowdsourced technique to track user gaze to drive the optimization and modeling; and (4) Evaluate the optimization and modeling specifically in terms of user experience by conducting large scale, crowdsourced, user evaluation.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK

por.por_cntn:
Web performance has long been crucial to the Internet ecosystem, given that a significant fraction of Internet content are consumed as Web pages. But there is a growing concern that the way that Page Load Time, or PLT is measured today does not adequately capture the user's Quality of Experience (QoE). This in turn means that optimizing the PLT metric may not improve user satisfaction. 

To this end, the goal of this project is to define, measure, and optimize the user Quality of Experience (QoE) of Web pages. The project makes innovations in the intersection of Computer systems, Cognitive Science, and Computer Vision. 

The crux of this work is based on a large scale user studies that shows that crowdsourced metric that measures when the user perceives a page to be loaded, does not correlate with traditional page load time metrics.
The main idea of the project is to define a user-perceived Page Load Time metric (or uPLT) and leverage user's eye gaze patterns to improve this uPLT metric.   The project then works towards (a) designing new techniques to optimize for the uPLT metric, (b) defining user engagement as a proxy for uPLT that can be inferred without requiring explicit user feedback, and (c) modeling and predicting user attention on Web pages. 

The results of the project are published as papers at Usenix (NSDI) Network Systems Design and Implementation, ACM (MobileHCI) Mobile Human Computer Interaction, and ACM (ETRA) Symposium on Eye Tracking Research and Application. The publications and other artifacts can be found at www.cs.stonybrook.edu/~arunab/gaze.

Intellectual Merit: The project resulted in three strands of research. First, a large scale crowdsourced study on both mobile and desktops to collect user perceived page load times across a large class of Web pages. This research thread included a system called WebGaze, that uses eye gaze tracking to identify parts of the page with high user attention. WebGaze then shows that prioritizing objects that have higher user attention can indeed improve the user's perception of when the page loaded.

The second strand of research, focussing on cognitive science, deals with the definition  and an implicit measure of user engagement using eye gaze. The project produced a reading detector that can detect when a user starts to read and engage with a page. The project also showed that user attention is highly dependent on the page ordering. Prior to this, there were no studies that showed the relationship between user attention and Web page ordering dynamics. 

The third strand of research, focussing on Computer Vision, deals with building attention models that can predict user attention on Web pages without requiring large-scale gaze data. The attention prediction system, called WebSalNet, takes into account the semantic of the Web pages. Using a two-state model, WebSalNet first predicts saliency maps of the web page and then uses layout-specific semantic components to predict where users attention will be drawn. Taken together, the three strands of research make considerable progress in understanding and improving user Quality of Experience for Web page loads.

Broader Impact: This research targets a broad segment of the population: the popularity of Web traffic on the Internet is unprecedented. At this scale, user experience is critical. Larger companies can use a dedicated engineering force to improve performance that  startups and smaller companies cannot afford.  The project paves the way to automate mechanisms for improving user experience for the Web, thus leveling the playing field. The project funded the research of three (3) graduate students in the areas of Computer Systems, Cognitive Science, and Computer Vision. All three students interacted with each other on all of the projects, getting exposed to multiple disciplines in the process.


Last Modified: 08/29/2021
Modified by: Aruna Balasubramanian
